name: Novoic
description:
Novoic is the world’s leading company applying speech as a clinical tool in neurological disease.

Leveraging world-class in-house machine learning research and the largest proprietary data-set of its kind, our technology detects the early signs of dementia decades before it’s done today - from just a short voice recording.

team.title: CTO
team.name: Jack Weston
team.bioHtml: Co-founder and CTO at Novoic – we're hiring! Predicting brain disease from speech. Oxford University grad, Cambridge University PhD.

jobs.title: Cloud Architect
jobs.description:
Senior Cloud Architect - Novoic
Paid. Full time.
Biotech AI startup detecting brain disease from speech


“Great to meet you - what brings you here?”


Alzheimer’s disease and other dementias will affect 1 out 3 people (~same as all cancers combined) yet there isn’t a single disease-modifying drug on the market. The problem is the lack of an easy, cheap, scalable way to detect the disease early enough.

Subtle changes in an Alzheimer’s patients’ speech appear 20-30 years before routine clinical diagnosis and - with good enough technology - can be detected reliably. Let’s get to work.


“... sorry, your name was?”

Novoic.

We’re a small, but fast growing, driven team of Oxford/Cambridge/Stanford machine learning researchers, neuroscientists, clinicians, and the exCEO of a top pharma company, backed by some of the best venture funds in Europe. We’re also a team of humans. Humans who are ambitious, humble, weird, brilliant, and here to get to work to solve some fundamentally hard problems. If we succeed the rewards will be almost inconceivable. And we come to work every morning (or afternoon depending on circadian rhythm) with a deep sense of meaning. We’re many more things, which you’ll experience if you come and talk with us.


“How can I help?”

We’ve made real progress to solve this problem. We’re the furthest ahead in building something that’s sustainable and scalable; that will work in the existing landscape now, and as it’s changing. But we still need a lot of help. And we need the extraordinary kind.


“Why do you need my help right now?”

Compliance, privacy, and data security are big deals to us. We need more expertise in our team building and scaling secure, compliant infrastructure for handling patient data. We're doing this in the right way. Our infrastructure is a key selling point for us, rather than something that’s simply evaluated as a security risk. And that’s hard and takes a lot of work. We need this to be the best work you’ve already done.
We’re growing and scaling up fast. This includes commercial partnerships and running large clinical studies, where we’ll have much more data to be good protectors off.
We’re not contracting this work because this is something that will be constantly evolving, needing constant maintenance, and is mission-critical.


“What kind of person are you looking for?”
Experienced. A lot. This is vocational expertise. You can’t learn this from a book/degree. The older and wiser the better. This is 1000% important.
Opinionated. You need to have firm opinions everywhere you see it important for security/uptime/etc. Especially if anyone on the tech team asks to do something you’re against. We’re a startup, moving and scaling fast, so this will happen. You need to be able to shout at the CTO if need be.
We’ll make unreasonable requests, both in terms of resources, time, feasibility – it’s up to you to stand your ground.


“What will I actually do?”
(Jointly) own the infrastructure - design, build/scale, maintain it; with our team and the help of consultants/contractors if need be.
Decide what resources we need (money, internal/external staff) and make a case for/request them.
Fight fires: be on call if things go wrong with e.g. the backend during a clinical trial. Once we’re deploying live products at scale, on-call duties will be split between the CTO and any other cloud architect/full-stack people on the team. We share the good stuff and share the boring stuff.
Brief, discuss and educate the CTO so they can make the best decisions and talk confidently to customers, investors, etc.
Make decisions on our tech stack jointly with the CTO and other members of your team.
Be extremely involved in the hiring process for non-research tech hires: design and lead algorithms interviews, intro calls, provide your opinion on candidates to the talent team.


Some must-have requirements
10+ years in industry as cloud/DevOps/automation engineer. Big company, small company - we don’t care. You just have to be great.
Spent your career mostly dealing with security/compliance (healthcare, fintech, etc.).
Did all of this on AWS.
This is recent experience. AWS changes a lot and keeping up is hard. It doesn’t count if you’ve been out of the full-stack game for years.
Very experienced with Java, Python.
Anything to do with product/UX/React Native/web dev/app dev is nice, but not a requirement.


What we’d love to give you if you join
Daily challenges, variety, flexibility. An insane learning curve (like the roads in that scene from Inception).
Insight, exposure, hands-on experience into how an early-stage venture-funded deep-tech/biotech startup works. A real, great one ;) We are a small team and fully transparent. You’ll see how clinical trials are organised, a healthcare product is built, a team is built, the biggest pharma companies are sold to.Sense of meaning (and bragging rights) that you have a significant role in changing the way brain diseases are diagnosed, making millions of patients’ lives better. Working on something we find meaningful is something our whole team deeply cares about and if you won’t have the same spark after about the second time you’ve spoken with us, we’re probably not a great fit for you.
Flexible working arrangements. If you need to leave early on Thursdays to pick up your kids from school, or work from home on a Monday while waiting for the plumber, go for it. As long as you’re producing insane work (and taking care of yourself/your family in the process), we’ve got your back.
6 weeks’ holiday per year.
Competitive compensation, including equity.

Applications received through our website/job board will be prioritised:
https://jobs.lever.co/novoic

jobs.title: Funding Intern
jobs.description:
**“Great to meet you – what brings you here?”** Alzheimer’s disease and other dementias will affect 1 out 3 people (~same as all cancers combined) yet there isn’t a single disease-modifying drug on the market. The problem is the lack of an easy, cheap, and scalable way to detect the disease early enough.  
Subtle changes in an Alzheimer’s patients’ speech appear 20-30 year before routine clinical diagnosis, and – with good enough technology – can be detected reliably. Let’s get to work.  
  
**“… sorry, your name was?”** Novoic.  
We’re a small, but fast growing, driven team of Oxford/Cambridge machine learning researchers, neuroscientists, clinicians and the exCEO of a top pharma company, backed by some of the best venture funds in Europe.  
Last year we developed a test that detects Alzheimer’s (and other neurological disease) from a few minutes of speech, recorded from a patient, 10-20 years before routine diagnosis.  
We’re also nice.  
  
**“How can I help?”**  
We’ve already completed proof of concept studies with really exciting results, and now it’s time to set up larger scale clinical trials to validate the technology further and in other diseases.  
The tech is game-changing and proven.The societal impact will be huge.Our team is great.Dozens of leading neurologists are keen to work with us.  
This means that there are many great opportunities for public funding available out there to help rolling out this technology. It will help millions of people and families, who’d otherwise suffer greatly – but compared to our ambitions and current growth we’re severely understaffed and need a superstar intern (you) to help us seize all of these opportunities.  
  
Starting ASAP, you’d be working directly with our founder/CEO and another key employee to- Identify the and evaluate most eligible grants and alternative funding opportunities.- Formulate strategy for the selected competitions.- Conduct extensive market research/analysis on Novoic's commercial opportunities.- Help manage relationships with our existing clinical/academic partners, organise co-applications for grants.- Writing the core of the applications.  
  
Crucial to our alternative funding strategy is fine-tuning our commercial strategy and doing incredible market research/analysis. Understanding our competitor landscape, customers and go-to-market strategy will increase our funding upshots.   
In short, you’ll be in charge of finding the best grants/funding competitions to apply for, creating a strategy for the applications, doing background market/customer research and analysis, writing the initial drafts, and finalising the applications.  
50-70% of your time will be spent writing the applications and doing the necessary market/customer research to make those applications absolutely stand out. In this process you’ll be representing the very best R&D in the field, and this needs to be reflected in the final applications.  
This includes writing/editing summaries of the scientific literature, learning what are the problems that grant/competition focuses on and how to communicate those perfectly (including the hidden ‘rules’ of grant writing which you’ll get from our team, your own research, and working with funding bodies and the best professional grant writers out there). 10-20% of time will be spent finding new competitions and academic/clinical partners we could co-apply with and then managing those relationships.  
You’ll have constant help from us and professional grant writer consultants we (or you?) will also hire. That said, this is not a dumb support role – we hope you’re up for the challenge to be proactive be the main driver of getting grant funding for our projects. Although a junior role, there’s close to unlimited responsibility you can earn, if you do good work.  
The rest of your time you’ll be working on whatever you find most exciting/impactful within the company – you can work with us setting up the trials you’re getting extra funding for, work with the technical team, help us with business development, etc.  
  
**Who we’re hoping to meet (you!):**  
- Available to start ASAP part time (20+ hours/week) or full time.- Available to stay with us for at least 3 months; candidates that can stay at least 6 months will be prioritised.- Preferably based in London, so that you can join us in the office once remote work arrangements end – this is important to us to make the team cohesive and in sync.- A superwoman/man. Someone who can work with our team to get (a lot of) work done, quickly. We don’t want you to hang around and make coffee – that’s not fun for you or really helpful for us to make lives better for patients.- Equipped with great scientific writing skills; producing consistently better output than your peers; high on creativity and comfortable with yourself as a writer.- Incredible market research/analysis skills with experience in financial modelling and business planning.- Someone with good analytical skills and intuition so evaluating and mapping out grant competitions can quickly become a piece of cake for you.- Comfortable with reviewing literature thoroughly and critically.- Extraordinarily proactive; both in pursuing your individual work, and building relationships with the people in and outside of the team that would help you best succeed in your role.- Preferably someone who worked in a fast-paced and idea rich environment before, where open and honest communication is central.- Want to learn a lot and work with some other great human beings.  
  
**What we’d love to give you if you join:**  
- Insight, exposure, hand-on experience into how an early-stage venture funded deep-tech/biotech startup works. We are a small team and fully transparent. You’ll work directly next to and with the founders and most welcome to attend/shadow/organise meetings. You’ll see how clinical trials are organised, a healthcare product is built, a team is built, the biggest pharma companies are sold to.- Skills. By default you’ll get amazing at market research/analysis and writing grant applications (taught by the best professionals we/you can hire) which is a skill we wish we had picked up sooner. Additionally you can help us with any other part of the business and learn anything you’re interested in and someone in the team knows about. This includes mentoring and tailored personal development led by one of the senior members of the team.- Sense of meaning (and bragging rights) that you have a significant role in changing the way brain diseases are diagnosed, making millions of patients’ lives better. Working on something we find meaningful is something our whole team deeply cares about and if you won’t have the same spark after about the second time you’ve spoken with us, we’re probably not a great fit for you.- Flexible working hours and location. You can work day or night or weekends – many of the core team is in the office anyways. Preferably you’d work with us in our London office around Angel/Old Street at least 1-2 days/week.-

jobs.title: Grants and Collaborations Intern
jobs.description:
Paid Internship. Part-time or Full-time.


“Great to meet you – what brings you here?”

Alzheimer’s disease and other dementias will affect 1 out 3 people (~same as all cancers combined) yet there isn’t a single disease-modifying drug on the market. The problem is the lack of an easy, cheap, and scalable way to detect the disease early enough.

Subtle changes in an Alzheimer’s patients’ speech appear 20-30 year before routine clinical diagnosis, and – with good enough technology – can be detected reliably. Let’s get to work.




“… sorry, your name was?”

Novoic.

We’re a small, but fast growing, driven team of Oxford/Cambridge machine learning researchers, neuroscientists, clinicians and the exCEO of a top pharma company, backed by some of the best venture funds in Europe.

Last year we developed a test that detects Alzheimer’s (and other neurological disease) from a few minutes of speech, recorded from a patient, 10-20 years before routine diagnosis.

We’re also nice.

 


“How can I help?”

We’ve already completed proof of concept studies with really exciting results, and now it’s time to set up larger scale clinical trials to validate the technology further and in other diseases.

- The tech is game-changing and proven.
- The societal impact will be huge.
- Our team is great.
- Dozens of leading neurologists are keen to work with us.

This means that there’s a many great opportunities for public funding available out there to help rolling out this technology to help millions of people and families, who’d otherwise suffer greatly – but compared to our ambitions and current growth we’re severely understaffed and need a superstar intern (you) to help us seize all of these opportunities.

Starting ASAP, you’d be working directly with our founder/CEO and another key employee to

- Identify the and evaluate most eligible grants and alternative funding opportunities.
- Formulate strategy for the selected competitions.
- Help manage relationships with our existing clinical/academic partners, organise co-applications for grants.
- Writing the core of the applications.
- Find and collaborate with professional grant writer consultants on writing/finalising applications.

In short, you’ll be in charge of finding the best grants to apply for, creating a strategy for the applications, doing background research and analysis, writing the initial drafts, and finalising the applications.

50-70% of your time will be spent writing the applications and doing the necessary research to make those applications absolutely stand out. In this process you’ll be representing the very best R&D in the field, and this needs to be reflected in the final applications.

This includes writing/editing summaries of the scientific literature, learning what are the problems that grant/competition focuses on and how to communicate those perfectly (including the hidden ‘rules’ of grant writing which you’ll get from our team, your own research, and working with funding bodies and the best professional grant writers out there). 10-20% of time will be spent finding new competitions and academic/clinical partners we could co-apply with and then managing those relationships.

You’ll have constant help from us and professional grant writer consultants we (or you?) will also hire. That said, this is not a dumb support role – we hope you’re up for the challenge to be proactive be the main driver of getting grant funding for our projects. Although a junior role, there’s close to unlimited responsibility you can earn, if you do good work.

The rest of your time you’ll be working on whatever you find most exciting/impactful within the company – you can work with us setting up the trials you’re getting extra funding for, work with the technical team, help us with business development, etc.




Who we’re hoping to meet (you!):

- available to start ASAP part time (20+ hours/week) or full time.
available to stay with us for at least 3 months; candidates that can stay at least 6 months will be prioritised.

- available to work with us in person in London regularly – this is important to us to make the team cohesive and in sync.

- A superwoman/man. Someone who can work with our team to get (a lot of) work done, quickly. We don’t want you to hang around and make coffee – that’s not fun for you or really helpful for us to make lives better for patients.
equipped with great scientific writing skills; producing consistently better output than your peers; high on creativity and comfortable with yourself as a writer.

- Someone with good analytical skills and intuition so evaluating and mapping out grant competitions can quickly become a piece of cake for you.

- comfortable with reviewing literature thoroughly and critically. Preferably in the process of or have completed a science/neuroscience BSc/Msc/PhD.
extraordinarily proactive; both in pursuing your individual work, and building relationships with the people in and outside of the team that would help you best succeed in your role.

- preferably someone who worked in a fast-paced and idea rich environment before, where open and honest communication is central.
want to learn a lot and work with some other great human beings.




What we’d love to give you if you join:

- Insight, exposure, hand-on experience into how an early-stage venture funded deep-tech/biotech startup works. A real, great one 😉 We are a small team and fully transparent. You’ll work directly next to and with the founders and most welcome to attend/shadow/organise meetings. You’ll see how clinical trials are organised, a healthcare product is built, a team is built, the biggest pharma companies are sold to.

- Skills. By default you’ll get amazing at writing grant applications (taught by the best professionals we/you can hire) which is a skill we wish we had picked up sooner. Additionally you can help us with any other part of the business and learn anything you’re interested in and someone in the team knows about. This includes mentoring and tailored personal development led by one of the senior members of the team.

- Sense of meaning (and bragging rights) that you have a significant role in changing the way brain diseases are diagnosed, making millions of patients’ lives better. Working on something we find meaningful is something our whole team deeply cares about and if you won’t have the same spark after about the second time you’ve spoken with us, we’re probably not a great fit for you.

- Flexible working hours and location. You can work day or night or weekends – many of the core team is in the office anyways. Preferably you’d work with us in our London office around Angel/Old Street at least 1-2 days/week.

- Collaborative compensation.
 

Applications received through our website/job board will be prioritised:
https://jobs.lever.co/novoic

50-70% of your time will be spent writing the applications and doing the necessary research to make those applications absolutely stand out. In this process you’ll be representing the very best R&D in the field, and this needs to be reflected in the final applications.

This includes writing/editing summaries of the scientific literature, learning what are the problems that grant/competition focuses on and how to communicate those perfectly (including the hidden ‘rules’ of grant writing which you’ll get from our team, your own research, and working with funding bodies and the best professional grant writers out there). 10-20% of time will be spent finding new competitions and academic/clinical partners we could co-apply with and then managing those relationships.

You’ll have constant help from us and professional grant writer consultants we (or you?) will also hire. That said, this is not a dumb support role – we hope you’re up for the challenge to be proactive be the main driver of getting grant funding for our projects. Although a junior role, there’s close to unlimited responsibility you can earn, if you do good work.

The rest of your time you’ll be working on whatever you find most exciting/impactful within the company – you can work with us setting up the trials you’re getting extra funding for, work with the technical team, help us with business development, etc.

Who we’re hoping to meet (you!):

  • available to start ASAP part time (20+ hours/week) or full time.
    available to stay with us for at least 3 months; candidates that can stay at least 6 months will be prioritised.

  • available to work with us in person in London regularly – this is important to us to make the team cohesive and in sync.

  • A superwoman/man. Someone who can work with our team to get (a lot of) work done, quickly. We don’t want you to hang around and make coffee – that’s not fun for you or really helpful for us to make lives better for patients.
    equipped with great scientific writing skills; producing consistently better output than your peers; high on creativity and comfortable with yourself as a writer.

  • Someone with good analytical skills and intuition so evaluating and mapping out grant competitions can quickly become a piece of cake for you.

  • comfortable with reviewing literature thoroughly and critically. Preferably in the process of or have completed a science/neuroscience BSc/Msc/PhD.
    extraordinarily proactive; both in pursuing your individual work, and building relationships with the people in and outside of the team that would help you best succeed in your role.

  • preferably someone who worked in a fast-paced and idea rich environment before, where open and honest communication is central.
    want to learn a lot and work with some other great human beings.

What we’d love to give you if you join:

  • Insight, exposure, hand-on experience into how an early-stage venture funded deep-tech/biotech startup works. A real, great one 😉 We are a small team and fully transparent. You’ll work directly next to and with the founders and most welcome to attend/shadow/organise meetings. You’ll see how clinical trials are organised, a healthcare product is built, a team is built, the biggest pharma companies are sold to.

  • Skills. By default you’ll get amazing at writing grant applications (taught by the best professionals we/you can hire) which is a skill we wish we had picked up sooner. Additionally you can help us with any other part of the business and learn anything you’re interested in and someone in the team knows about. This includes mentoring and tailored personal development led by one of the senior members of the team.

  • Sense of meaning (and bragging rights) that you have a significant role in changing the way brain diseases are diagnosed, making millions of patients’ lives better. Working on something we find meaningful is something our whole team deeply cares about and if you won’t have the same spark after about the second time you’ve spoken with us, we’re probably not a great fit for you.

  • Flexible working hours and location. You can work day or night or weekends – many of the core team is in the office anyways. Preferably you’d work with us in our London office around Angel/Old Street at least 1-2 days/week.

  • Collaborative compensation.

Applications received through our website/job board will be prioritised:
https://jobs.lever.co/novoic

jobs.title: Machine Learning Intern
jobs.description:
Novoic, a London-based digital biotech company, is seeking a Machine Learning Intern to help us advance our state-of-the-art research in speech analytics for predicting and understanding neurological disease. Being part of a rapidly-scaling startup means you will have the work closely with our Research Scientists, contribute to cutting-edge research with access to proprietary data, have a huge impact on the lives of patients, and have exposure to various aspects of the company.

As a Machine Learning Intern, you will work both independently and in collaboration with the rest of our R&D team. We are looking for a driven scientist with an entrepreneurial spirit who will produce world-class research and help turn it into real products that benefit patients.

Responsibilities:
•	Work closely with the R&D team to produce world-class medical research to predict and understand neurological disease from voice using computational linguistics and deep learning
•	Collaborate with software engineers to help turn this research into real-world products
•	Contribute to scientific posters and papers for conferences

Requirements:
•	Currently pursuing or previously completed a PhD or master’s degree in Computational Linguistics, Machine Learning, Computer Science, Natural Language Processing, Speech Processing, Signal Processing, Bioinformatics, Statistics or a similar technical field
•	Familiarity with Python and a deep learning framework such as TensorFlow/Keras
•	Experience with supervised, unsupervised or reinforcement learning techniques
•	Ability to take initiative and work independently as a researcher in a fast-paced environment
•	Strong scientific communication skills, preferably evidenced by published academic research
•	Strong interpersonal communication skills

Benefits & perks:
•	Competitive compensation including equity options
•	4 weeks’ holiday per annum
•	Fast career progression in a rapidly-scaling startup
•	Opportunity to publish your research and attend global conferences

About Novoic

Novoic is a London-based digital biotech company predicting brain disease from the way you speak – decades before routine diagnosis. Our research lies at the intersection of computational linguistics, deep learning and neuroscience. We believe having your brain health checked should be as easy as having a conversation. Our team has a diverse range of backgrounds, including Oxford/Cambridge researchers, clinicians and the former CEO of a top-5 global pharmaceutical company. Novoic is backed by Entrepreneur First, the leading talent investor in Europe, and the Oxford University L.E.V8 accelerator.



Applications received through our website/job board will be prioritised:
https://jobs.lever.co/novoic

jobs.title: Research Engineer
jobs.description:
Research Engineer - NovoicPaid. Full time.Biotech AI startup detecting brain disease from speech  
  
**“Great to meet you - what brings you here?”**  
Alzheimer’s disease and other dementias will affect 1 out 3 people (~same as all cancers combined) yet there isn’t a single disease-modifying drug on the market. The problem is the lack of an easy, cheap, scalable way to detect the disease early enough.  
Subtle changes in an Alzheimer’s patients’ speech appear 20-30 years before routine clinical diagnosis and – with good enough technology – can be detected reliably. Let’s get to work.  
**“... sorry, your name was?”**  
Novoic.  
We’re a small, but fast growing, driven team of Oxford/Cambridge/Stanford machine learning researchers, neuroscientists, clinicians, and the exCEO of a top pharma company, backed by some of the best venture funds in Europe. We’re also a team of humans. Humans who are ambitious, humble, weird, brilliant, and here to get to work to solve some fundamentally hard problems. If we succeed the rewards will be almost inconceivable. And we come to work every morning (or afternoon depending on circadian rhythm) with a deep sense of meaning. We’re many more things, which you’ll experience if you come and talk with us.  
  
**“How can I help?”**  
We’ve made real progress to solve this problem. We’re the furthest ahead in building something that’s sustainable and scalable; that will work in the existing landscape now, and as it’s changing. But we still need a lot of help. And we need the extraordinary kind.  
  
**“Why do you need my help right now?”**  
We’re already by far producing best-in-class research in NLP, speech/language understanding etc and a major bottleneck for us is capacity – having more hands to do great ML implementations here. That said, we know there are many even better ideas out there we haven’t thought of and need people even smarter than us, that we can work with to work out what those are.  
  
**“What kind of person are you looking for?”**  
- Bursting with ML ideas (particularly deep signal processing, NLP, audio and text representations – and things we don’t know yet are important; tell us). Every time you read a new paper (which is often) it sparks a rich range of applications, related ideas, or combination of ideas.- Natural communicator of complex concepts. Can read an ML paper and explain it to your grandparents in an engaging way (including grandparents that didn’t work on neural net models in the 70s).- Obsessive doer that executes well. Someone who feels they always need to code things up that they read in papers (or better yet– code something up that’s better or shows how the paper is limited). Hungry for data.  
  
**“What will I actually do?”**  
Read mountains of cutting-edge NLP/DL/signal processing papers, synthesize research and generate ideas (= application of ideas to our domain), synthesis of multiple ideas or entirely new ones. This could be papers such as:[Towards Robust Image Classification Using Sequential Attention Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/1912.02184)[Continuous Hierarchical Representations with Poincaré Variational Auto-Encoders](https://arxiv.org/abs/1901.06033)[On the Cross-lingual Transferability of Monolingual Representations](https://arxiv.org/abs/1901.06033)[Zero-shot Word Sense Disambiguation using Sense Definition Embeddings](https://www.aclweb.org/anthology/P19-1568/)[Ordered Neurons: Integrating Tree Structures into Recurrent Neural Networks](https://arxiv.org/abs/1810.09536)[Audio-Linguistic Embeddings for Spoken Sentences](https://arxiv.org/abs/1902.07817)  
- Have ongoing relationships and discussions with the best academics in the field to push the mutual research agenda.- Code up and try out lots of ideas quickly.- Take ownership of your research. Present your work to the rest of the team. Bring the best ideas to proof-of-concept or production level. If your idea is promising, lead a project and organise the other REs.- Be a conscientious engineer when it counts (i.e.  all the time except for quick mock-ups of ideas): minimizing technical debt through commenting, documentation, tracking.- Scientific communication: writing papers, material for IP filings, making plots/graphics for customers.- Don’t work in isolation, use the rest of the R&D team for ideas sharing, problem solving etc. Do your part to make this an academic community, but one that gets things done like a tech startup.- Be extremely structured about the research/project management. This is the only way we can make research go fast without drowning. Conducting literature reviews, change logging, benchmarking etc.- AUTOMATION AUTOMATION AUTOMATION. You will contribute to making everything we do as automatic and as interpretable as possible. CI/CD pipelines, automatic benchmarking of models etc. This will be a core part of the job. We are obsessed with automation and visualisation.  
  
**Some must-have requirements**  
- Degree from top university in comp sci/ML/maths/physics/etc. Or have done something that demonstrates equivalent (or greater) talents and skills.- 3+ years of research experience in ML or applying ML, preferably for audio/linguistics (academic or industry, PhD great).Very strong coding skills in Python, which will be probed in the interview process.  
  
**What we’d love to give you if you join**  
- Daily challenges, variety, flexibility. An insane learning curve (like the roads in that scene from Inception).- Insight, exposure, hands-on experience into how an early-stage venture-funded deep-tech/biotech startup works. A real, great one ;) - We are a small team and fully transparent. You’ll see how clinical trials are organised, a healthcare product is built, a team is built, the biggest pharma companies are sold to.- Sense of meaning (and bragging rights) that you have a significant role in changing the way brain diseases are diagnosed, making millions of patients’ lives better. Working on something we find meaningful is something our whole team deeply cares about and if you won’t have the same spark after about the second time you’ve spoken with us, we’re probably not a great fit for you.- Flexible working arrangements. If you need to leave early on Thursdays to pick up your kids from school, or work from home on a - -Monday while waiting for the plumber, go for it. As long as you’re producing insane work (and taking care of yourself/your family in the process), we’ve got your back.- You’ll be an author on any paper you contribute to. We’ll soon be publishing the most influential work in our field, based on our cutting-edge research and unique datasets. Being a contributor to these papers is going to be hard work – but the upside will be huge.- 6 weeks’ holiday per year.- Competitive compensation, including equity.

“Great to meet you - what brings you here?”

Alzheimer’s disease and other dementias will affect 1 out 3 people (~same as all cancers combined) yet there isn’t a single disease-modifying drug on the market. The problem is the lack of an easy, cheap, scalable way to detect the disease early enough.

Subtle changes in an Alzheimer’s patients’ speech appear 20-30 years before routine clinical diagnosis and – with good enough technology – can be detected reliably. Let’s get to work.

“... sorry, your name was?”

Novoic.

We’re a small, but fast growing, driven team of Oxford/Cambridge/Stanford machine learning researchers, neuroscientists, clinicians, and the exCEO of a top pharma company, backed by some of the best venture funds in Europe. We’re also a team of humans. Humans who are ambitious, humble, weird, brilliant, and here to get to work to solve some fundamentally hard problems. If we succeed the rewards will be almost inconceivable. And we come to work every morning (or afternoon depending on circadian rhythm) with a deep sense of meaning. We’re many more things, which you’ll experience if you come and talk with us.

“How can I help?”

We’ve made real progress to solve this problem. We’re the furthest ahead in building something that’s sustainable and scalable; that will work in the existing landscape now, and as it’s changing. But we still need a lot of help. And we need the extraordinary kind.

“Why do you need my help right now?”

We’re already by far producing best-in-class research in NLP, speech/language understanding etc and a major bottleneck for us is capacity – having more hands to do great ML implementations here. That said, we know there are many even better ideas out there we haven’t thought of and need people even smarter than us, that we can work with to work out what those are.

“What kind of person are you looking for?”

  • Bursting with ML ideas (particularly deep signal processing, NLP, audio and text representations – and things we don’t know yet are important; tell us). Every time you read a new paper (which is often) it sparks a rich range of applications, related ideas, or combination of ideas.
  • Natural communicator of complex concepts. Can read an ML paper and explain it to your grandparents in an engaging way (including grandparents that didn’t work on neural net models in the 70s).
  • Obsessive doer that executes well. Someone who feels they always need to code things up that they read in papers (or better yet– code something up that’s better or shows how the paper is limited). Hungry for data.

“What will I actually do?”

Read mountains of cutting-edge NLP/DL/signal processing papers, synthesize research and generate ideas (= application of ideas to our domain), synthesis of multiple ideas or entirely new ones.
This could be papers such as:
Towards Robust Image Classification Using Sequential Attention Models
Continuous Hierarchical Representations with Poincaré Variational Auto-Encoders
On the Cross-lingual Transferability of Monolingual Representations
Zero-shot Word Sense Disambiguation using Sense Definition Embeddings
Ordered Neurons: Integrating Tree Structures into Recurrent Neural Networks
Audio-Linguistic Embeddings for Spoken Sentences

  • Have ongoing relationships and discussions with the best academics in the field to push the mutual research agenda.
  • Code up and try out lots of ideas quickly.
  • Take ownership of your research. Present your work to the rest of the team. Bring the best ideas to proof-of-concept or production level. If your idea is promising, lead a project and organise the other REs.
  • Be a conscientious engineer when it counts (i.e. all the time except for quick mock-ups of ideas): minimizing technical debt through commenting, documentation, tracking.
  • Scientific communication: writing papers, material for IP filings, making plots/graphics for customers.
  • Don’t work in isolation, use the rest of the R&D team for ideas sharing, problem solving etc. Do your part to make this an academic community, but one that gets things done like a tech startup.
  • Be extremely structured about the research/project management. This is the only way we can make research go fast without drowning. Conducting literature reviews, change logging, benchmarking etc.
  • AUTOMATION AUTOMATION AUTOMATION. You will contribute to making everything we do as automatic and as interpretable as possible. CI/CD pipelines, automatic benchmarking of models etc. This will be a core part of the job. We are obsessed with automation and visualisation.

Some must-have requirements

  • Degree from top university in comp sci/ML/maths/physics/etc. Or have done something that demonstrates equivalent (or greater) talents and skills.
  • 3+ years of research experience in ML or applying ML, preferably for audio/linguistics (academic or industry, PhD great). Very strong coding skills in Python, which will be probed in the interview process.

What we’d love to give you if you join

  • Daily challenges, variety, flexibility. An insane learning curve (like the roads in that scene from Inception).
  • Insight, exposure, hands-on experience into how an early-stage venture-funded deep-tech/biotech startup works. A real, great one ;) - We are a small team and fully transparent. You’ll see how clinical trials are organised, a healthcare product is built, a team is built, the biggest pharma companies are sold to.
  • Sense of meaning (and bragging rights) that you have a significant role in changing the way brain diseases are diagnosed, making millions of patients’ lives better. Working on something we find meaningful is something our whole team deeply cares about and if you won’t have the same spark after about the second time you’ve spoken with us, we’re probably not a great fit for you.
  • Flexible working arrangements. If you need to leave early on Thursdays to pick up your kids from school, or work from home on a - -Monday while waiting for the plumber, go for it. As long as you’re producing insane work (and taking care of yourself/your family in the process), we’ve got your back.
  • You’ll be an author on any paper you contribute to. We’ll soon be publishing the most influential work in our field, based on our cutting-edge research and unique datasets. Being a contributor to these papers is going to be hard work – but the upside will be huge.
  • 6 weeks’ holiday per year.
  • Competitive compensation, including equity.

Applications received through our website/job board will be prioritised:
https://jobs.lever.co/novoic
skills: Computer Vision, Machine Learning, Robotics, Deep Learning

jobs.title: Research Scientist
jobs.description:
Novoic, a London-based digital biotech company, is seeking a Research Scientist to help us advance our state-of-the-art research in speech/language analytics for predicting and understanding neurological disease. Being part of a rapidly-scaling startup means you will have the opportunity to be a leader in this field, publish cutting-edge research with access to proprietary data, have a huge impact on the lives of patients, and move quickly into senior roles in the company.

As a Research Scientist, you will work both independently and in collaboration with software developers and the rest of our R&D team. We are looking for a driven scientist with an entrepreneurial spirit who will produce world-class research and help turn it into real products that benefit patients.

Responsibilities:
•	Produce world-class linguistic research to predict and understand neurological disease from voice using deep learning
•	Collaborate with software engineers to help turn this research into real-world products
•	Help draft patent applications based on your research
•	Stay at the bleeding edge of computational linguistics, natural language processing, speech processing and machine learning
•	Collaborate with senior management to inform research directions
•	Write/present posters and papers at global conferences

Requirements:
•	PhD or significant experience as a researcher in commercial or academic environments
•	PhD or master’s degree in Computational Linguistics, Machine Learning, Natural Language Processing, Speech Processing, Signal Processing, Bioinformatics, Statistics or a related technical field
•	Familiarity with Python and a deep learning framework such as TensorFlow/Keras
•	Experience using supervised, unsupervised or reinforcement learning techniques
•	Ability to take initiative and work independently as a researcher in a fast-paced environment
•	Strong scientific communication skills, evidenced by published academic research
•	Strong interpersonal communication skills

Benefits & perks:
•	Competitive compensation including equity options
•	4 weeks’ holiday per annum
•	Fast career progression in a rapidly-scaling startup
•	Opportunity to publish your research and attend global conferences

About Novoic

Novoic is a London-based digital biotech company predicting brain disease from the way you speak – decades before routine diagnosis. Our research lies at the intersection of computational linguistics, deep learning and neuroscience. We believe having your brain health checked should be as easy as having a conversation. Our team has a diverse range of backgrounds, including Oxford/Cambridge researchers, clinicians and the former CEO of a top-5 global pharmaceutical company. Novoic is backed by Entrepreneur First, the leading talent investor in Europe, and the Oxford University L.E.V8 accelerator.

How to apply

Applications received through our website/job board will be prioritised:
https://jobs.lever.co/novoic

jobs.title: Senior Clinical Project Manager
jobs.description:
Senior Clinical Manager / Senior Clinical Operations Manager
Full-time / Part-time
London, UK or remote

Alzheimer’s disease affects 1 out 3 people (~same as cancer) yet there isn’t a single disease-modifying drug on the market. The problem is the lack of an easy and scalable way to detect the disease early enough.

Subtle changes in an Alzheimer’s patient’s speech appear 20-30 year before routine clinical diagnosis. With good enough technology, these subtle changes can be detected reliably. 

We’re a small, driven team of mostly Oxford/Cambridge machine learning researchers and neuroscientists. Backed by some of the best neurologists and venture capital firms of Europe, we’re working together to make speech the game changer diagnostic modality of neurological disease. 

Last year we developed the base of our technology and completed proof of concept studies with really promising results. Now it’s time to set up a number of  clinical trials to validate the technology further and in other diseases. 

None of our core team has extensive experience running clinical trials and/or getting regulatory approvals and we need someone to help us run these studies much more efficiently and professionally than we ourselves could.

Joining us, you will be our team’s much needed internal expert in setting up and operating clinical trials, working with us and our advisors closely to create and then execute our regulatory and clinical science strategy. You will initially have an end to end role - helping us both with planning our studies and with day to day operations.


Your tasks will most likely include:
Helping us decide what are the best trials to run, and how to run them to achieve business and regulatory goals as soon as possible.
Helping us writing and editing protocols, patient information sheets, consent forms SOPs and other key documents regarding our trials.
Helping with trial start-up, setting up data capture, data management and reporting processes.
Helping with or performing investigational site qualifications, interim and site close-out monitoring visits, including addressing site issues/monitoring action items during on-site visits.
Communicating, maintaining good relationships with all participating investigator sites and their research staff. Potentially coordinate investigator meetings.
Reviewing clinical data and investigator site files for completeness, clarity and conflicts. Issuing data queries as needed to resolve inconsistencies.
Liaising with notified bodies, preparing TMFs and all clinical data for regulatory submissions.


You will be responsible ensuring that our trials run according to GCP, HiPAA, GDPR and all other applicable standards. You will be smarter and more experienced than us in most of the tasks you will perform. This also means that you’re going to have a role that evolves quickly as the company grows, our clinical programs progress, or just as we learn - perhaps right from you - about what we need to do. 


My hope is that after we had a few in-depth conversations about the company, what our goals are and where are we in our clinical program you and us together  will be able to create a much more precise job description for you.


As an ideal candidate you
Have 5-10+ years of experience in the clinical trial/regulatory space. 
Are comfortable working without constant supervision and being the person in our team with the most experience and knowledge on operating clinical trials and complying with regulatory processes.
Have years of hands on experience with all or most of the tasks outlined above, know GCP and other related guidelines inside-out.
Ideally have worked in the past as a Clinical Research Associate/Clinical Research Coordinator/Project Manager in a prestigious CRO ANDHave experience working in a regulatory agency or as a regulatory consultant in the field.
Submitted or helped to prepare successful regulatory submissions. You may have an Extensive knowledge and understanding of US, EU, and Global Medical Device regulations, standards and guidance documents. Regulatory Affairs Certification preferred (US or EU).
Preferably you have experience preparing and maintaining US and non-US product submissions, technical files and international registrations.
Ideally have your  experience more working (also) with medical devices instead of solely on drug trials.
Have scientific/medical writing skills and comfortable writing or editing key documents regarding the trial

Additionally and importantly, you are also a super-reliable person who’s a pleasure to work with. You are able to work in a fast paced environment, but you with great attention to the smallest details we wouldn’t even notice. You take ownership of your tasks, but love collaborating on projects and you don’t mind mentoring and sharing your knowledge with less experienced team members so you can work together better.


We’re doing our best to make the logistics working with us as easy and comfortable as possible.
Our office is in London (Angel/Old Street area). We’d prefer having you around us, but the location of work is flexible - you can be based anywhere across the UK or US as long as we can meet in person regularly. We might need you to travel occasionally for on-site visits.
Similarly, working hours are also flexible and can based on what we agree on initially can be almost anytime. It would be great to have you available for a few hours at least across the whole week, in case there is something urgent we need your help with.
Generous holiday and compensation package.
Starting date as part- time would be ASAP. The date and option of conversion to a full-time role is something to discuss/decide once we find the perfect applicant.


At the start, this is most likely going to be a part-time role potentially expanding quickly into a full-time opportunity - it’s flexible.


Applications received through our website/job board will be prioritised:
https://jobs.lever.co/novoic

If we succeed the rewards will be almost inconceivable. And we come to work every morning (or afternoon depending on circadian rhythm) with a deep sense of meaning. We’re many more things, which you’ll experience if you come and talk with us.

“How can I help?”

We’ve made real progress to solve this problem. We’re the furthest ahead in building something that’s sustainable and scalable; that will work in the existing landscape now, and as it’s changing. But we still need a lot of help. And we need the extraordinary kind.

“Why do you need my help right now?”

Compliance, privacy, and data security are big deals to us. We need more expertise in our team building and scaling secure, compliant infrastructure for handling patient data. We're doing this in the right way. Our infrastructure is a key selling point for us, rather than something that’s simply evaluated as a security risk. And that’s hard and takes a lot of work. We need this to be the best work you’ve already done.We’re growing and scaling up fast. This includes commercial partnerships and running large clinical studies, where we’ll have much more data to be good protectors off.We’re not contracting this work because this is something that will be constantly evolving, needing constant maintenance, and is mission-critical.

“What kind of person are you looking for?” Experienced. A lot. This is vocational expertise. You can’t learn this from a book/degree. The older and wiser the better. This is 1000% important.Opinionated. You need to have firm opinions everywhere you see it important for security/uptime/etc. Especially if anyone on the tech team asks to do something you’re against. We’re a startup, moving and scaling fast, so this will happen. You need to be able to shout at the CTO if need be.We’ll make unreasonable requests, both in terms of resources, time, feasibility – it’s up to you to stand your ground.

“What will I actually do?” (Jointly) own the infrastructure - design, build/scale, maintain it; with our team and the help of consultants/contractors if need be.Decide what resources we need (money, internal/external staff) and make a case for/request them.Fight fires: be on call if things go wrong with e.g. the backend during a clinical trial. Once we’re deploying live products at scale, on-call duties will be split between the CTO and any other cloud architect/full-stack people on the team. We share the good stuff and share the boring stuff.Brief, discuss and educate the CTO so they can make the best decisions and talk confidently to customers, investors, etc.Make decisions on our tech stack jointly with the CTO and other members of your team.Be extremely involved in the hiring process for non-research tech hires: design and lead algorithms interviews, intro calls, provide your opinion on candidates to the talent team.

Some must-have requirements 10+ years in industry as cloud/DevOps/automation engineer. Big company, small company - we don’t care. You just have to be great.Spent your career mostly dealing with security/compliance (healthcare, fintech, etc.).Did all of this on AWS.This is recent experience. AWS changes a lot and keeping up is hard. It doesn’t count if you’ve been out of the full-stack game for years.Very experienced with Java, Python.Anything to do with product/UX/React Native/web dev/app dev is nice, but not a requirement.

What we’d love to give you if you join Daily challenges, variety, flexibility. An insane learning curve (like the roads in that scene from Inception).Insight, exposure, hands-on experience into how an early-stage venture-funded deep-tech/biotech startup works. A real, great one ;) We are a small team and fully transparent. You’ll see how clinical trials are organised, a healthcare product is built, a team is built, the biggest pharma companies are sold to.Sense of meaning (and bragging rights) that you have a significant role in changing the way brain diseases are diagnosed, making millions of patients’ lives better. Working on something we find meaningful is something our whole team deeply cares about and if you won’t have the same spark after about the second time you’ve spoken with us, we’re probably not a great fit for you.Flexible working arrangements. If you need to leave early on Thursdays to pick up your kids from school, or work from home on a Monday while waiting for the plumber, go for it. As long as you’re producing insane work (and taking care of yourself/your family in the process), we’ve got your back.6 weeks’ holiday per year.Competitive compensation, including equity.

jobs.title: Special Ops (data, execution)
jobs.description:
Special Ops. - Novoic
Paid. Full time.
Biotech AI startup detecting brain disease from speech


“Great to meet you - what brings you here?”

Alzheimer’s disease and other dementias will affect 1 out 3 people (~same as all cancers combined) yet there isn’t a single disease-modifying drug on the market. The problem is the lack of an easy, cheap, scalable way to detect the disease early enough.
Subtle changes in an Alzheimer’s patients’ speech appear 20-30 years before routine clinical diagnosis and - with good enough technology - can be detected reliably. Let’s get to work.


“... sorry, your name was?”

Novoic.

We’re a small, but fast growing, driven team of Oxford/Cambridge/Stanford machine learning researchers, neuroscientists, clinicians, and the exCEO of a top pharma company, backed by some of the best venture funds in Europe.

We’re also a team of humans. Humans who are ambitious, humble, weird, brilliant, and here to get to work to solve some fundamentally hard problems. If we succeed the rewards will be almost inconceivable. And we come to work every morning (or afternoon depending on circadian rhythm) with a deep sense of meaning. We’re many more things, which you’ll experience if you come and talk with us.


“How can I help?”

We’ve made real progress to solve this problem. We’re the furthest ahead in building something that’s sustainable and scalable; that will work in the existing landscape now, and as it’s changing. But we still need a lot of help. And we need the extraordinary kind.
“Why do we need your help right now?”
We’re here to win. We know how to win. You’ll be an important part of this. That’s why we need you.
Data is important to winning our game. Decentralised today with many small institutions running their own studies. We believe there’s power in bringing these smaller institutions together and working with them. More details for late stage candidates.
Moving fast on this is core part of the CEO's high level strategy, so we need you right now. This is a Special Ops. role and you’ll be working directly with the CEO to execute on this.


“What will I actually do?”

- Something not listed here within the first week.
- But: finding and obtaining access to existing datasets.
- Building relationships with academic groups, hospitals (or more precisely - building relationships with the right stakeholders there).
- Brokering IP and licence agreements.
- Travelling. Sometimes not, sometimes a lot. Sometimes within the UK, sometimes out of.


Who we’re hoping to meet (you!)

- This one is hard. Honestly we’re not sure what we need. I’m putting this out because of the asymmetric returns if we happen to get this right for the candidate. But you might know better, who we’re really looking for.
- Credible to doctors and leading professors. Highly professional.
In depth, serious scientific discussions with same. Reads scientific papers Sunday morning.
- You probably need to be 1:10.000 top communicator/interpersonal skills (high empathy).
- Exceptional in execution.
- “Win-win” negotiator (you’ll be assessed on this through the interview process).
- Into how software is eating biology and healthcare. You need to have some conceptual understanding of how ML works, but don’t need to be a hands on coder.
- High G-factor. This role has high uncertainty/fluidity/complexity and we know it will change, sometimes weekly.
- This is our role with the highest requirements; but if you’re the right candidate, you will have one of the most challenging and exciting roles you could dream off.


For all our roles we ask the following: we want unconventional people. Who solves impossible problems. Who table flips the checkers board when losing “because it’s a stupid game requiring no strategy” and proposes to switch to alpha-go (chess is sooo February 1996). Ideally someone who tries to make up new rules.


You need to have an appetite to work on fundamentally hard problems; a glass-is-overflowing type of person; that laughs at the 9th failed attempt.
We want people who grow naturally (professionally and more importantly as human beings), that we can grow, and who can grow us. A+++ but we actually mean it.



Most important: you need to have a good reason for being here and wanting to work with us.


Some must-have requirements. You have/are:

- MD/PhD in neurology.
- 1:10.000 top communicator.
- Experience with IP/licencing.
- You might have moved from Mayo Clinic to Google Health; then a fast riser in companies such as Flatiron, Owkin, Tempus, Prognos, Linguamatics, HortonWorks, IQVIA.


Practically speaking You are

- Ideally able to start ASAP. Full time.
- If you’re good we want you to stay for long (+2y) so this needs to be at least theoretically possible.
- Available to work with us in person in London regularly - this is important to us to make the team cohesive and in sync.
- That said, expect to travel a lot. Both within the UK and outside of the UK.


What we’d love to give you if you join

- This is our role with the highest requirements; but if you’re the right candidate, you will have one of the most challenging and exciting roles you could dream of.
- This is a Special Ops. role and you’ll be working directly with the CEO to execute on key strategic imperatives.
- Daily challenges, variety, flexibility. An insane learning curve (like the roads in that scene from Inception).
- Insight, exposure, hands-on experience into how an early-stage venture funded deep-tech/biotech startup works. A real, great one ;) We are a small team and fully transparent. You’ll see how clinical trials are organised, a healthcare product is built, a team is built, the biggest pharma companies are sold to.
- Sense of meaning (and bragging rights) that you have a significant role in changing the way brain diseases are diagnosed, making millions of patients’ lives better. Working on something we find meaningful is something our whole team deeply cares about and if you won’t have the same spark after about the second time you’ve spoken with us, we’re probably not a great fit for you.
- Flexible working hours and location. You can work day or night or weekends - many of the core team is in the office anyway. Preferably you’d work with us in our London office around Angel/Old Street at least 2-3 days/week (the circumstances around travel laid out considered.

Applications received through our job board will be looked at earlier.
https://jobs.lever.co/novoic

jobs.title: Wildcard
jobs.description:
We're always most happy to hear from great people who don't fit any of our categories! If you're one of these people, this is the role to put in an application for. Submit your CV, write a few lines, and we'll be in touch if there's a fit.  
If you do decide to apply as a 'Wildcard' (and please do! - we always love hearing from amazing people) make sure to attach or write a few lines on - what's your dream role, what is it that you envision yourself working on in Novoic.- why do you think we should have that role in Novoic.- why you're the single best person in the world for that role.  
Wildcard CVs without context are unlikely to receive a reply from us.Thank you. Excited to read your application!
